statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

article.description: Seventh-ranked North Carolina got off to a fast start at the ACC Tournament as the regular-season champion routed Pittsburgh 88-71 Thursday to take the first step toward its first conference titl

video.headline: UNC runs past Pitt
video.caption: North Carolina beat Pittsburgh 88-71 to advance to the semifinals of the ACC Tournament.

video.headline: Will loss to UNC impact Pitt's seeding?
video.caption: ESPN Bracketology Insider Joe Lunardi doesn't believe Pittsburgh's loss to North Carolina will impact its seeding and says the Panthers are on the cutline between the last four byes and the last four in.

images.caption: Marcus Paige was limited to eight points in North Carolina's win over Pitt at the ACC Tournament. Outings like that have become more common this year.

related.description: Marcus Paige hasn't been himself all season. Even he admits it. If North Carolina wants to win the ACC tournament -- and a national title -- the Tar Heels need a better version of Paige.
related.linkText: North Carolina needs more from Marcus Paige
related.title: North Carolina Tar Heels have to get bigger contribution from senior Marcus Paige
related.headline: If North Carolina wants to win a title, the Tar Heels need a better Marcus Paige

article.headline: No. 7 UNC opens ACC Tournament by topping Pitt 88-71

images.name: UNC runs past Pitt
images.caption: North Carolina beat Pittsburgh 88-71 to advance to the semifinals of the ACC Tournament.

article.linkText: No. 7 UNC opens ACC Tournament by topping Pitt 88-71
article.story:
WASHINGTON -- Seventh-ranked North Carolina was shooting so well that arena workers had to replace the fraying net at one end of the floor at halftime. In the second half, the Tar Heels gave the other net a workout.

The regular-season ACC champion looked every bit like it, shooting 58.9 percent on the way to an 88-71 rout of Pittsburgh on Thursday in the quarterfinals of the conference tournament. By putting together the fourth-best shooting performance in ACC Tournament history, UNC (26-6) took its initial step toward its first conference title since 2008.

"Just having the balance of the inside-outside attack, that helped us out a lot," said leading scorer Joel Berry II, who had 20 on 7-of-8 shooting. "In the second half, I think we got better movement than we did in the first half. That was a big key."

Roy Williams nodded as Berry talked about the improved ball movement, and UNC's coach pointed to a 10-0 run late in the first half as the difference. Williams was ready to tear into his team at halftime before it got six straight stops to rebound from an early deficit.

"We decided we were going to lock down and play the way we wanted to play, and that's when the momentum started to change," said forward Brice Johnson, who scored 19 points on 8-of-11 shooting and added 10 rebounds. "We just fed off of that the last five minutes of the first half."

Pitt (21-11) tied it at 45 with 15:52 left, but then the Tar Heels got rolling. An 11-0 run keyed by an assist and 3-pointer from freshman guard Kenny Williams III put the game out of reach.

UNC was feeling it, and the Panthers couldn't stem the tide in front of a boisterous partisan crowd wearing baby blue. After looking spry early, players eventually got worn down playing their second game in as many afternoons.

"I certainly thought we would have finished off better than we did," Pitt coach Jamie Dixon said. "The defense struggled the entire game. Eventually it caught up to us as they pulled away in the second half."

Forwards Jamel Artis and Michael Young each scored 19 to lead the Panthers, who still should make the NCAA tournament despite the loss. Gunning for a No. 1 seed, UNC next faces either No. 19 Duke or Notre Dame in the ACC semifinals Friday night.

The Tar Heels lost at Notre Dame and split with archrival Duke.

"We do know these teams because we've seen them play all season long," Williams said. "We'll try to give them the three or four most important things and let it go at that."

KENNY KILLS PITT

Williams' 3-pointer during the big second-half run was the first of his college career after starting 0 for 12. It was the seldom-played guard's first shot attempt since Valentine's Day.

"He hasn't been able to throw it in the ocean," Williams said. "He made his shot."

PITT'S NCAA CASE

Pitt entered ranked 53rd in the RPI with the 41st-toughest strength of schedule and is 8-8 against top-50 opponents. Dixon thought the Panthers were in "pretty good shape" after beating Syracuse, so they should still be NCAA tournament-bound.

"Everybody seems to be telling us we are," Dixon said Thursday. "I haven't looked at everything going on. Just from what everybody says."

TIP-INS

Pittsburgh: Artis started the game on a personal 8-0 run. ... Cameron Johnson and James Robinson, the heroes of the second-round win against Syracuse, combined to shoot 5 of 18 from the field. ... With his fourth assist, Robinson became the fifth player in school history to reach 600 in his career.

North Carolina: Four players scored in double-figures. ... Reached the ACC tournament semifinals for the fifth time in the past six years. ... The Tar Heels improved to 5-0 in neutral-site games this season.

UP NEXT

North Carolina: Faces the winner of No. 19 Duke vs. Notre Dame in semifinals Friday.
